## [§](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/#rustcrypto-rsa)[RustCrypto](https://github.com/RustCrypto/): RSA
[![crates.io](https://buildstats.info/crate/rsa)](https://crates.io/crates/rsa) [![Documentation](https://docs.rs/rsa/badge.svg)](https://docs.rs/rsa) [![Build Status](https://github.com/rustcrypto/RSA/workflows/CI/badge.svg)](https://github.com/RustCrypto/RSA/actions?query=workflow%3ACI+branch%3Amaster) [![dependency status](https://deps.rs/repo/github/RustCrypto/RSA/status.svg)](https://deps.rs/repo/github/RustCrypto/RSA) ![MSRV](https://img.shields.io/badge/rustc-1.65+-blue.svg) [![Project Chat](https://img.shields.io/badge/zulip-join_chat-blue.svg)](https://rustcrypto.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/260047-RSA)
A portable RSA implementation in pure Rust.
### [§](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/#example)Example
```
use rsa::{Pkcs1v15Encrypt, RsaPrivateKey, RsaPublicKey};
let mut rng = rand::thread_rng(); // rand@0.8
let bits = 2048;
let priv_key = RsaPrivateKey::new(&mut rng, bits).expect("failed to generate a key");
let pub_key = RsaPublicKey::from(&priv_key);
// Encrypt
let data = b"hello world";
let enc_data = pub_key.encrypt(&mut rng, Pkcs1v15Encrypt, &data[..]).expect("failed to encrypt");
assert_ne!(&data[..], &enc_data[..]);
// Decrypt
let dec_data = priv_key.decrypt(Pkcs1v15Encrypt, &enc_data).expect("failed to decrypt");
assert_eq!(&data[..], &dec_data[..]);
```

> **Note:** If you encounter unusually slow key generation time while using `RsaPrivateKey::new` you can try to compile in release mode or add the following to your `Cargo.toml`. Key generation is much faster when building with higher optimization levels, but this will increase the compile time a bit.
> ```
[profile.debug]
opt-level = 3
```

> If you don’t want to turn on optimizations for all dependencies, you can only optimize the `num-bigint-dig` dependency. This should give most of the speedups.
> ```
[profile.dev.package.num-bigint-dig]
opt-level = 3
```

### [§](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/#status)Status
Currently at Phase 1 (v) 🚧
There will be three phases before `1.0` 🚢 can be released.
  1. 🚧 Make it work 
     * Prime generation ✅
     * Key generation ✅
     * PKCS1v1.5: Encryption & Decryption ✅
     * PKCS1v1.5: Sign & Verify ✅
     * PKCS1v1.5 (session key): Encryption & Decryption
     * OAEP: Encryption & Decryption
     * PSS: Sign & Verify
     * Key import & export
  2. 🚀 Make it fast 
     * Benchmarks ✅
     * compare to other implementations 🚧
     * optimize 🚧
  3. 🔐 Make it secure 
     * Fuzz testing
     * Security Audits


### [§](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/#security-warning)⚠️Security Warning
This crate has received one [security audit by Include Security](https://www.opentech.fund/results/security-safety-audits/deltachat/), with only one minor finding which has since been addressed.
See the [open security issues](https://github.com/RustCrypto/RSA/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3Asecurity) on our issue tracker for other known problems.
~~Notably the implementation of[modular exponentiation is not constant time](https://github.com/RustCrypto/RSA/issues/19), but timing variability is masked using [random blinding](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blinding_\(cryptography\)), a commonly used technique.~~ This crate is vulnerable to the [Marvin Attack](https://people.redhat.com/~hkario/marvin/) which could enable private key recovery by a network attacker (see [RUSTSEC-2023-0071](https://rustsec.org/advisories/RUSTSEC-2023-0071.html)).
You can follow our work on mitigating this issue in [#390](https://github.com/RustCrypto/RSA/issues/390).
### [§](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/#minimum-supported-rust-version-msrv)Minimum Supported Rust Version (MSRV)
All crates in this repository support Rust 1.65 or higher.
In the future MSRV can be changed, but it will be done with a minor version bump.

## [§](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/#supported-algorithms)Supported algorithms
This crate supports several schemes described in [RFC8017](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8017#section-8.1):
  * [OAEP encryption scheme](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/#oaep-encryption)
  * [PKCS#1 v1.5 encryption scheme](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/#pkcs1-v15-encryption)
  * [PKCS#1 v1.5 signature scheme](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/#pkcs1-v15-signatures)
  * [PSS signature scheme](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/#pss-signatures)


These schemes are described below.
## [§](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/#usage)Usage
### [§](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/#oaep-encryption)OAEP encryption
Note: requires `sha2` feature of `rsa` crate is enabled.
```
use rsa::{RsaPrivateKey, RsaPublicKey, Oaep, sha2::Sha256};
let mut rng = rand::thread_rng(); // rand@0.8
let bits = 2048;
let private_key = RsaPrivateKey::new(&mut rng, bits).expect("failed to generate a key");
let public_key = RsaPublicKey::from(&private_key);
// Encrypt
let data = b"hello world";
let padding = Oaep::new::<Sha256>();
let enc_data = public_key.encrypt(&mut rng, padding, &data[..]).expect("failed to encrypt");
assert_ne!(&data[..], &enc_data[..]);
// Decrypt
let padding = Oaep::new::<Sha256>();
let dec_data = private_key.decrypt(padding, &enc_data).expect("failed to decrypt");
assert_eq!(&data[..], &dec_data[..]);
```

### [§](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/#pkcs1-v15-encryption)PKCS#1 v1.5 encryption
```
use rsa::{RsaPrivateKey, RsaPublicKey, Pkcs1v15Encrypt};
let mut rng = rand::thread_rng(); // rand@0.8
let bits = 2048;
let private_key = RsaPrivateKey::new(&mut rng, bits).expect("failed to generate a key");
let public_key = RsaPublicKey::from(&private_key);
// Encrypt
let data = b"hello world";
let enc_data = public_key.encrypt(&mut rng, Pkcs1v15Encrypt, &data[..]).expect("failed to encrypt");
assert_ne!(&data[..], &enc_data[..]);
// Decrypt
let dec_data = private_key.decrypt(Pkcs1v15Encrypt, &enc_data).expect("failed to decrypt");
assert_eq!(&data[..], &dec_data[..]);
```

### [§](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/#pkcs1-v15-signatures)PKCS#1 v1.5 signatures
Note: requires `sha2` feature of `rsa` crate is enabled.
```
use rsa::RsaPrivateKey;
use rsa::pkcs1v15::{SigningKey, VerifyingKey};
use rsa::signature::{Keypair, RandomizedSigner, SignatureEncoding, Verifier};
use rsa::sha2::{Digest, Sha256};
let mut rng = rand::thread_rng(); // rand@0.8
let bits = 2048;
let private_key = RsaPrivateKey::new(&mut rng, bits).expect("failed to generate a key");
let signing_key = SigningKey::<Sha256>::new(private_key);
let verifying_key = signing_key.verifying_key();
// Sign
let data = b"hello world";
let signature = signing_key.sign_with_rng(&mut rng, data);
assert_ne!(signature.to_bytes().as_ref(), data.as_slice());
// Verify
verifying_key.verify(data, &signature).expect("failed to verify");
```

### [§](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/#pss-signatures)PSS signatures
Note: requires `sha2` feature of `rsa` crate is enabled.
```
use rsa::RsaPrivateKey;
use rsa::pss::{BlindedSigningKey, VerifyingKey};
use rsa::signature::{Keypair,RandomizedSigner, SignatureEncoding, Verifier};
use rsa::sha2::{Digest, Sha256};
let mut rng = rand::thread_rng(); // rand@0.8
let bits = 2048;
let private_key = RsaPrivateKey::new(&mut rng, bits).expect("failed to generate a key");
let signing_key = BlindedSigningKey::<Sha256>::new(private_key);
let verifying_key = signing_key.verifying_key();
// Sign
let data = b"hello world";
let signature = signing_key.sign_with_rng(&mut rng, data);
assert_ne!(signature.to_bytes().as_ref(), data);
// Verify
verifying_key.verify(data, &signature).expect("failed to verify");
```

### [§](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/#pkcs1-rsa-key-encoding)PKCS#1 RSA Key Encoding
PKCS#1 supports a legacy format for encoding RSA keys as binary (DER) or text (PEM) data.
You can recognize PEM encoded PKCS#1 keys because they have “RSA * KEY” in the type label, e.g.:
```
-----BEGIN RSA PRIVATE KEY-----
```

Most modern applications use the newer PKCS#8 format instead (see below).
The following traits can be used to decode/encode [`RsaPrivateKey`](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/struct.RsaPrivateKey.html "struct rsa::RsaPrivateKey") and [`RsaPublicKey`](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/struct.RsaPublicKey.html "struct rsa::RsaPublicKey") as PKCS#1. Note that [`pkcs1`](https://docs.rs/pkcs1/0.7.5/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/pkcs1/index.html "mod pkcs1") is re-exported from the toplevel of the `rsa` crate:
  * [`pkcs1::DecodeRsaPrivateKey`](https://docs.rs/pkcs1/0.7.5/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/pkcs1/traits/trait.DecodeRsaPrivateKey.html "trait pkcs1::traits::DecodeRsaPrivateKey"): decode RSA private keys from PKCS#1
  * [`pkcs1::EncodeRsaPrivateKey`](https://docs.rs/pkcs1/0.7.5/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/pkcs1/traits/trait.EncodeRsaPrivateKey.html "trait pkcs1::traits::EncodeRsaPrivateKey"): encode RSA private keys to PKCS#1
  * [`pkcs1::DecodeRsaPublicKey`](https://docs.rs/pkcs1/0.7.5/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/pkcs1/traits/trait.DecodeRsaPublicKey.html "trait pkcs1::traits::DecodeRsaPublicKey"): decode RSA public keys from PKCS#1
  * [`pkcs1::EncodeRsaPublicKey`](https://docs.rs/pkcs1/0.7.5/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/pkcs1/traits/trait.EncodeRsaPublicKey.html "trait pkcs1::traits::EncodeRsaPublicKey"): encode RSA public keys to PKCS#1


#### [§](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/#example-1)Example
```
use rsa::{RsaPublicKey, pkcs1::DecodeRsaPublicKey};
let pem = "-----BEGIN RSA PUBLIC KEY-----
MIIBCgKCAQEAtsQsUV8QpqrygsY+2+JCQ6Fw8/omM71IM2N/R8pPbzbgOl0p78MZ
GsgPOQ2HSznjD0FPzsH8oO2B5Uftws04LHb2HJAYlz25+lN5cqfHAfa3fgmC38Ff
wBkn7l582UtPWZ/wcBOnyCgb3yLcvJrXyrt8QxHJgvWO23ITrUVYszImbXQ67YGS
0YhMrbixRzmo2tpm3JcIBtnHrEUMsT0NfFdfsZhTT8YbxBvA8FdODgEwx7u/vf3J
9qbi4+Kv8cvqyJuleIRSjVXPsIMnoejIn04APPKIjpMyQdnWlby7rNyQtE4+CV+j
cFjqJbE/Xilcvqxt6DirjFCvYeKYl1uHLwIDAQAB
-----END RSA PUBLIC KEY-----";
let public_key = RsaPublicKey::from_pkcs1_pem(pem)?;
```

### [§](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/#pkcs8-rsa-key-encoding)PKCS#8 RSA Key Encoding
PKCS#8 is a private key format with support for multiple algorithms. Like PKCS#1, it can be encoded as binary (DER) or text (PEM).
You can recognize PEM encoded PKCS#8 keys because they _don’t_ have an algorithm name in the type label, e.g.:
```
-----BEGIN PRIVATE KEY-----
```

The following traits can be used to decode/encode [`RsaPrivateKey`](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/struct.RsaPrivateKey.html "struct rsa::RsaPrivateKey") and [`RsaPublicKey`](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/struct.RsaPublicKey.html "struct rsa::RsaPublicKey") as PKCS#8. Note that [`pkcs8`](https://docs.rs/pkcs8/0.10.2/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/pkcs8/index.html "mod pkcs8") is re-exported from the toplevel of the `rsa` crate:
  * [`pkcs8::DecodePrivateKey`](https://docs.rs/pkcs8/0.10.2/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/pkcs8/traits/trait.DecodePrivateKey.html "trait pkcs8::traits::DecodePrivateKey"): decode private keys from PKCS#8
  * [`pkcs8::EncodePrivateKey`](https://docs.rs/pkcs8/0.10.2/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/pkcs8/traits/trait.EncodePrivateKey.html "trait pkcs8::traits::EncodePrivateKey"): encode private keys to PKCS#8
  * [`pkcs8::DecodePublicKey`](https://docs.rs/pkcs8/latest/pkcs8/trait.DecodePublicKey.html): decode public keys from PKCS#8
  * [`pkcs8::EncodePublicKey`](https://docs.rs/pkcs8/latest/pkcs8/trait.EncodePublicKey.html): encode public keys to PKCS#8


#### [§](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/#example-2)Example
```
use rsa::{RsaPublicKey, pkcs8::DecodePublicKey};
let pem = "-----BEGIN PUBLIC KEY-----
MIIBIjANBgkqhkiG9w0BAQEFAAOCAQ8AMIIBCgKCAQEAtsQsUV8QpqrygsY+2+JC
Q6Fw8/omM71IM2N/R8pPbzbgOl0p78MZGsgPOQ2HSznjD0FPzsH8oO2B5Uftws04
LHb2HJAYlz25+lN5cqfHAfa3fgmC38FfwBkn7l582UtPWZ/wcBOnyCgb3yLcvJrX
yrt8QxHJgvWO23ITrUVYszImbXQ67YGS0YhMrbixRzmo2tpm3JcIBtnHrEUMsT0N
fFdfsZhTT8YbxBvA8FdODgEwx7u/vf3J9qbi4+Kv8cvqyJuleIRSjVXPsIMnoejI
n04APPKIjpMyQdnWlby7rNyQtE4+CV+jcFjqJbE/Xilcvqxt6DirjFCvYeKYl1uH
LwIDAQAB
-----END PUBLIC KEY-----";
let public_key = RsaPublicKey::from_public_key_pem(pem)?;
```

## Re-exports[§](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/#reexports)

`pub use crate::errors::Error[](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/errors/enum.Error.html "enum rsa::errors::Error");`


`pub use crate::errors::Result[](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/errors/type.Result.html "type rsa::errors::Result");`


`pub use crate::oaep::Oaep[](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/oaep/struct.Oaep.html "struct rsa::oaep::Oaep");`


`pub use crate::pkcs1v15::Pkcs1v15Encrypt[](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/pkcs1v15/struct.Pkcs1v15Encrypt.html "struct rsa::pkcs1v15::Pkcs1v15Encrypt");`


`pub use crate::pkcs1v15::Pkcs1v15Sign[](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/pkcs1v15/struct.Pkcs1v15Sign.html "struct rsa::pkcs1v15::Pkcs1v15Sign");`


`pub use crate::pss::Pss[](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/pss/struct.Pss.html "struct rsa::pss::Pss");`


`pub use rand_core[](https://docs.rs/rand_core/0.6.4/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/rand_core/index.html "mod rand_core");`


`pub use signature[](https://docs.rs/signature/2.2.0/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/signature/index.html "mod signature");`


`pub use pkcs1[](https://docs.rs/pkcs1/0.7.5/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/pkcs1/index.html "mod pkcs1");`


`pub use pkcs8[](https://docs.rs/pkcs8/0.10.2/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/pkcs8/index.html "mod pkcs8");`


`pub use sha2[](https://docs.rs/sha2/0.10.9/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/sha2/index.html "mod sha2");``sha2`

## Modules[§](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/#modules)

[errors](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/errors/index.html "mod rsa::errors")
    Error types.

[hazmat](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/hazmat/index.html "mod rsa::hazmat")`hazmat`
    ⚠️ Low-level “hazmat” RSA functions.

[oaep](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/oaep/index.html "mod rsa::oaep")
    Encryption and Decryption using [OAEP padding](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8017#section-7.1).

[pkcs1v15](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/pkcs1v15/index.html "mod rsa::pkcs1v15")
    PKCS#1 v1.5 support as described in [RFC8017 § 8.2](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8017#section-8.2).

[pss](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/pss/index.html "mod rsa::pss")
    Support for the [Probabilistic Signature Scheme](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probabilistic_signature_scheme) (PSS) a.k.a. RSASSA-PSS.

[traits](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/traits/index.html "mod rsa::traits")
    RSA-related trait definitions.
## Structs[§](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/#structs)

[BigUint](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/struct.BigUint.html "struct rsa::BigUint")
    A big unsigned integer type.

[CrtValue](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/struct.CrtValue.html "struct rsa::CrtValue")
    Contains the precomputed Chinese remainder theorem values.

[RsaPrivateKey](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/struct.RsaPrivateKey.html "struct rsa::RsaPrivateKey")
    Represents a whole RSA key, public and private parts.

[RsaPublicKey](https://docs.rs/rsa/latest/rsa/struct.RsaPublicKey.html "struct rsa::RsaPublicKey")
    Represents the public part of an RSA key.

## §⟨4⟩RustCrypto⟨5⟩: RSA
![crates.io⟨6⟩](https://crates.io/crates/rsa) ![Documentation⟨7⟩](https://docs.rs/rsa) ![Build Status⟨8⟩](https://github.com/RustCrypto/RSA/actions?query=workflow%3ACI+branch%3Amaster) ![dependency status⟨9⟩](https://deps.rs/repo/github/RustCrypto/RSA) ![MSRV⟨10⟩] ![Project Chat⟨11⟩](https://rustcrypto.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/260047-RSA)
A portable RSA implementation in pure Rust.
### §⟨12⟩Example
```
use rsa::{Pkcs1v15Encrypt, RsaPrivateKey, RsaPublicKey};
let mut rng = rand::thread_rng(); // rand@0.8
let bits = 2048;
let priv_key = RsaPrivateKey::new(&mut rng, bits).expect("failed to generate a key");
let pub_key = RsaPublicKey::from(&priv_key);
// Encrypt
let data = b"hello world";
let enc_data = pub_key.encrypt(&mut rng, Pkcs1v15Encrypt, &data[..]).expect("failed to encrypt");
assert_ne!(&data[..], &enc_data[..]);
// Decrypt
let dec_data = priv_key.decrypt(Pkcs1v15Encrypt, &enc_data).expect("failed to decrypt");
assert_eq!(&data[..], &dec_data[..]);
```

> **Note:** If you encounter unusually slow key generation time while using `RsaPrivateKey::new` you can try to compile in release mode or add the following to your `Cargo.toml`. Key generation is much faster when building with higher optimization levels, but this will increase the compile time a bit.
> ```
[profile.debug]
opt-level = 3
```

> If you don’t want to turn on optimizations for all dependencies, you can only optimize the `num-bigint-dig` dependency. This should give most of the speedups.
> ```
[profile.dev.package.num-bigint-dig]
opt-level = 3
```

### §⟨13⟩Status
Currently at Phase 1 (v) 🚧
There will be three phases before `1.0` 🚢 can be released.
  1. 🚧 Make it work 
     * Prime generation ✅
     * Key generation ✅
     * PKCS1v1.5: Encryption & Decryption ✅
     * PKCS1v1.5: Sign & Verify ✅
     * PKCS1v1.5 (session key): Encryption & Decryption
     * OAEP: Encryption & Decryption
     * PSS: Sign & Verify
     * Key import & export
  2. 🚀 Make it fast 
     * Benchmarks ✅
     * compare to other implementations 🚧
     * optimize 🚧
  3. 🔐 Make it secure 
     * Fuzz testing
     * Security Audits


### §⟨14⟩⚠️Security Warning
This crate has received one security audit by Include Security⟨15⟩, with only one minor finding which has since been addressed.
See the open security issues⟨16⟩ on our issue tracker for other known problems.
~~Notably the implementation ofmodular exponentiation is not constant time⟨17⟩, but timing variability is masked using random blinding⟨18⟩), a commonly used technique.~~ This crate is vulnerable to the Marvin Attack⟨19⟩ which could enable private key recovery by a network attacker (see RUSTSEC-2023-0071⟨20⟩).
You can follow our work on mitigating this issue in #390⟨21⟩.
### §⟨22⟩Minimum Supported Rust Version (MSRV)
All crates in this repository support Rust 1.65 or higher.
In the future MSRV can be changed, but it will be done with a minor version bump.

## §⟨27⟩Supported algorithms
This crate supports several schemes described in RFC8017⟨28⟩:
  * OAEP encryption scheme⟨29⟩
  * PKCS#1 v1.5 encryption scheme⟨30⟩
  * PKCS#1 v1.5 signature scheme⟨31⟩
  * PSS signature scheme⟨32⟩


These schemes are described below.
## §⟨33⟩Usage
### §⟨29⟩OAEP encryption
Note: requires `sha2` feature of `rsa` crate is enabled.
```
use rsa::{RsaPrivateKey, RsaPublicKey, Oaep, sha2::Sha256};
let mut rng = rand::thread_rng(); // rand@0.8
let bits = 2048;
let private_key = RsaPrivateKey::new(&mut rng, bits).expect("failed to generate a key");
let public_key = RsaPublicKey::from(&private_key);
// Encrypt
let data = b"hello world";
let padding = Oaep::new::<Sha256>();
let enc_data = public_key.encrypt(&mut rng, padding, &data[..]).expect("failed to encrypt");
assert_ne!(&data[..], &enc_data[..]);
// Decrypt
let padding = Oaep::new::<Sha256>();
let dec_data = private_key.decrypt(padding, &enc_data).expect("failed to decrypt");
assert_eq!(&data[..], &dec_data[..]);
```

### §⟨30⟩PKCS#1 v1.5 encryption
```
use rsa::{RsaPrivateKey, RsaPublicKey, Pkcs1v15Encrypt};
let mut rng = rand::thread_rng(); // rand@0.8
let bits = 2048;
let private_key = RsaPrivateKey::new(&mut rng, bits).expect("failed to generate a key");
let public_key = RsaPublicKey::from(&private_key);
// Encrypt
let data = b"hello world";
let enc_data = public_key.encrypt(&mut rng, Pkcs1v15Encrypt, &data[..]).expect("failed to encrypt");
assert_ne!(&data[..], &enc_data[..]);
// Decrypt
let dec_data = private_key.decrypt(Pkcs1v15Encrypt, &enc_data).expect("failed to decrypt");
assert_eq!(&data[..], &dec_data[..]);
```

### §⟨31⟩PKCS#1 v1.5 signatures
Note: requires `sha2` feature of `rsa` crate is enabled.
```
use rsa::RsaPrivateKey;
use rsa::pkcs1v15::{SigningKey, VerifyingKey};
use rsa::signature::{Keypair, RandomizedSigner, SignatureEncoding, Verifier};
use rsa::sha2::{Digest, Sha256};
let mut rng = rand::thread_rng(); // rand@0.8
let bits = 2048;
let private_key = RsaPrivateKey::new(&mut rng, bits).expect("failed to generate a key");
let signing_key = SigningKey::<Sha256>::new(private_key);
let verifying_key = signing_key.verifying_key();
// Sign
let data = b"hello world";
let signature = signing_key.sign_with_rng(&mut rng, data);
assert_ne!(signature.to_bytes().as_ref(), data.as_slice());
// Verify
verifying_key.verify(data, &signature).expect("failed to verify");
```

### §⟨32⟩PSS signatures
Note: requires `sha2` feature of `rsa` crate is enabled.
```
use rsa::RsaPrivateKey;
use rsa::pss::{BlindedSigningKey, VerifyingKey};
use rsa::signature::{Keypair,RandomizedSigner, SignatureEncoding, Verifier};
use rsa::sha2::{Digest, Sha256};
let mut rng = rand::thread_rng(); // rand@0.8
let bits = 2048;
let private_key = RsaPrivateKey::new(&mut rng, bits).expect("failed to generate a key");
let signing_key = BlindedSigningKey::<Sha256>::new(private_key);
let verifying_key = signing_key.verifying_key();
// Sign
let data = b"hello world";
let signature = signing_key.sign_with_rng(&mut rng, data);
assert_ne!(signature.to_bytes().as_ref(), data);
// Verify
verifying_key.verify(data, &signature).expect("failed to verify");
```

### §⟨34⟩PKCS#1 RSA Key Encoding
PKCS#1 supports a legacy format for encoding RSA keys as binary (DER) or text (PEM) data.
You can recognize PEM encoded PKCS#1 keys because they have “RSA * KEY” in the type label, e.g.:
```
-----BEGIN RSA PRIVATE KEY-----
```

Most modern applications use the newer PKCS#8 format instead (see below).
The following traits can be used to decode/encode `RsaPrivateKey`⟨35⟩ and `RsaPublicKey`⟨36⟩ as PKCS#1. Note that `pkcs1`⟨37⟩ is re-exported from the toplevel of the `rsa` crate:
  * `pkcs1::DecodeRsaPrivateKey`⟨38⟩: decode RSA private keys from PKCS#1
  * `pkcs1::EncodeRsaPrivateKey`⟨39⟩: encode RSA private keys to PKCS#1
  * `pkcs1::DecodeRsaPublicKey`⟨40⟩: decode RSA public keys from PKCS#1
  * `pkcs1::EncodeRsaPublicKey`⟨41⟩: encode RSA public keys to PKCS#1


#### §⟨42⟩Example
```
use rsa::{RsaPublicKey, pkcs1::DecodeRsaPublicKey};
let pem = "-----BEGIN RSA PUBLIC KEY-----
MIIBCgKCAQEAtsQsUV8QpqrygsY+2+JCQ6Fw8/omM71IM2N/R8pPbzbgOl0p78MZ
GsgPOQ2HSznjD0FPzsH8oO2B5Uftws04LHb2HJAYlz25+lN5cqfHAfa3fgmC38Ff
wBkn7l582UtPWZ/wcBOnyCgb3yLcvJrXyrt8QxHJgvWO23ITrUVYszImbXQ67YGS
0YhMrbixRzmo2tpm3JcIBtnHrEUMsT0NfFdfsZhTT8YbxBvA8FdODgEwx7u/vf3J
9qbi4+Kv8cvqyJuleIRSjVXPsIMnoejIn04APPKIjpMyQdnWlby7rNyQtE4+CV+j
cFjqJbE/Xilcvqxt6DirjFCvYeKYl1uHLwIDAQAB
-----END RSA PUBLIC KEY-----";
let public_key = RsaPublicKey::from_pkcs1_pem(pem)?;
```

### §⟨43⟩PKCS#8 RSA Key Encoding
PKCS#8 is a private key format with support for multiple algorithms. Like PKCS#1, it can be encoded as binary (DER) or text (PEM).
You can recognize PEM encoded PKCS#8 keys because they _don’t_ have an algorithm name in the type label, e.g.:
```
-----BEGIN PRIVATE KEY-----
```

The following traits can be used to decode/encode `RsaPrivateKey`⟨35⟩ and `RsaPublicKey`⟨36⟩ as PKCS#8. Note that `pkcs8`⟨44⟩ is re-exported from the toplevel of the `rsa` crate:
  * `pkcs8::DecodePrivateKey`⟨45⟩: decode private keys from PKCS#8
  * `pkcs8::EncodePrivateKey`⟨46⟩: encode private keys to PKCS#8
  * `pkcs8::DecodePublicKey`⟨47⟩: decode public keys from PKCS#8
  * `pkcs8::EncodePublicKey`⟨48⟩: encode public keys to PKCS#8


#### §⟨49⟩Example
```
use rsa::{RsaPublicKey, pkcs8::DecodePublicKey};
let pem = "-----BEGIN PUBLIC KEY-----
MIIBIjANBgkqhkiG9w0BAQEFAAOCAQ8AMIIBCgKCAQEAtsQsUV8QpqrygsY+2+JC
Q6Fw8/omM71IM2N/R8pPbzbgOl0p78MZGsgPOQ2HSznjD0FPzsH8oO2B5Uftws04
LHb2HJAYlz25+lN5cqfHAfa3fgmC38FfwBkn7l582UtPWZ/wcBOnyCgb3yLcvJrX
yrt8QxHJgvWO23ITrUVYszImbXQ67YGS0YhMrbixRzmo2tpm3JcIBtnHrEUMsT0N
fFdfsZhTT8YbxBvA8FdODgEwx7u/vf3J9qbi4+Kv8cvqyJuleIRSjVXPsIMnoejI
n04APPKIjpMyQdnWlby7rNyQtE4+CV+jcFjqJbE/Xilcvqxt6DirjFCvYeKYl1uH
LwIDAQAB
-----END PUBLIC KEY-----";
let public_key = RsaPublicKey::from_public_key_pem(pem)?;
```

errors⟨52⟩
    Error types.

hazmat⟨53⟩`hazmat`
    ⚠️ Low-level “hazmat” RSA functions.

## Structs§⟨61⟩

BigUint⟨62⟩
    A big unsigned integer type.

CrtValue⟨63⟩
    Contains the precomputed Chinese remainder theorem values.

RsaPrivateKey⟨35⟩
    Represents a whole RSA key, public and private parts.

RsaPublicKey⟨36⟩
    Represents the public part of an RSA key.

readme_summary: The `rsa` crate provides a pure Rust implementation of RSA cryptography, supporting key generation, encryption, decryption, signing, and verification using schemes like PKCS#1 v1.5, OAEP, and PSS as defined in RFC 8017. It includes features for encoding/decoding keys in PKCS#1 and PKCS#8 formats, supports customizable padding algorithms, and ensures compatibility with Rust 1.65+. While it has undergone security audits, it is actively addressing vulnerabilities like the Marvin Attack.
factual_counterfactual:
### Pair 1: Key Generation
✅ Factual: The `rsa` crate supports generating RSA private keys using the `RsaPrivateKey::new` method, which allows specifying the key size in bits (e.g., 2048 bits).  
❌ Counterfactual: The `rsa` crate does not support generating RSA private keys and requires importing keys from external sources.

---

### Pair 2: Encryption Schemes
✅ Factual: The `rsa` crate supports both PKCS#1 v1.5 and OAEP encryption schemes, with OAEP requiring the `sha2` feature to be enabled for hashing algorithms like `Sha256`.  
❌ Counterfactual: The `rsa` crate only supports PKCS#1 v1.5 encryption and does not implement OAEP encryption.

---

### Pair 3: Security Audits
✅ Factual: The `rsa` crate has undergone a security audit by Include Security, which identified and resolved one minor finding. However, it remains vulnerable to the Marvin Attack (RUSTSEC-2023-0071).  
❌ Counterfactual: The `rsa` crate has never been audited for security vulnerabilities and does not have any known security issues.
